revision.text:
An '''annotated bibliography''' is a [[bibliography]] that gives a summary of each of the entries.<ref>[http://www.lc.unsw.edu.au/onlib/annotated_bib.html ''What is an Annotated Bibliography?''] by the [[University of New South Wales]] The Learning Centre</ref> The purpose of [[annotations]] is to provide the reader with a summary and an evaluation of each source. Each summary should be a concise exposition of the source's central idea(s) and give the reader a general idea of the source's content.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bibliographies|url=http://writing.ku.edu/bibliographies|website=KU Writing Center|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=annbib3>{{cite web |title=Annotated Bibliographies|author=Geoff Stacks, Erin Karper |year=2001 |publisher=Purdue University |url=http://owl.english.purdue.edu/handouts/general/gl_annotatedbib.html |accessdate=2009-10-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080907132223/http://owl.english.purdue.edu/handouts/general/gl_annotatedbib.html| archivedate=September 7, 2008<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
== Main Components of Annotated Bibliographies == The following are the main components of an annotated bibliography. It is important to note that not all fields shown below must be used at once in an annotated bibliography. The fields may vary depending on the type of annotated bibliography and special instructions from the instructor in case the bibliography is part of a school assignment. * '''Full bibliographic citation :''' An annotated bibliography must contain the necessary and complete bibliographical information i.e. (author, title, publisher and date, etc), * '''Author’s Background:''' You should provide the name, authority, experience, or qualifications of the author. * '''Purpose of the work:''' You should provide the reasons why the author wrote the work * '''Scope of the work:''' You should state the breadth or depth of coverage and topics or sub-topics covered. * '''Main argument:''' State the main informative points of the paper * '''Audience:''' For whom was it written (general public, subject specialists, student? * '''Methodology:''' What methodology and research methods did the work employ? * '''Viewpoint:''' What is the author’s perspective or approach (school of thought, etc.)? Do you detect an unacknowledged bias, or find any undefended assumptions? * '''Sources:''' Does the author cite other sources, and if so, what types? Is it based on the author’s own research? Is it personal opinion? * '''Reliability of the source:''' How reliable is the work? * '''Conclusion:''' What does the author conclude about the work? Is the conclusion justified by the work? * '''Features:''' Any significant extras, e.g. visual aids (charts, maps, etc.), reprints of source documents, an annotated bibliography? * '''Strengths and Weaknesses:''' What are the strengths and weaknesses of the work? * '''Comparison:''' How does the source relate to other works done by other writers on the topic: does it agree or disagree with another author or a particular school of thought; are there other works which would support or dispute it? * '''Your Voice / Personal Conclusion:''' Provide your point of view of the work or your reaction to the source based on other available works, prior knowledge of the subject matter or knowledge pools done by other researchers.
==Types of annotations== Annotations may be written with different goals in mind. There are three types of annotations, depending on what might be most important for your reader or according to your professor’s instructions.It is impossible to describe a standard procedure for all types of annotations because one annotation does not fit all purposes. In order to know the best type of annotation, it is prudent to consult your instructor or follow the instructions. For example, if the assignment states that your annotative bibliography should give evidence proving an analytical understanding of the sources you have used, then you are supposed to write an analytical annotated bibliography which includes evaluation of the sources you are using. The three types of annotated bibliographies are; summary annotations, critical annotations and a combination of the former two.
'''Summary annotations'''
Summary annotations are further classified into informative and indicative annotations.
The following are the main features of summary annotations: * They show a summary of the source content * They highlight the arguments and proofs/evidence mentioned in the work * They sometimes describe the author’s methodology and any theories used * They offer the conclusion of the source * They do not evaluate the work they are discussing '''Informative Annotations'''
This type of annotation is a summary of the source. An informative annotation should include the thesis of the work, arguments or hypothesis, proofs and a conclusion.<ref name=annbib>{{cite web |url=http://www.wisc.edu/writing/Handbook/AnnBib_content.html |title=Annotated Bibliographies: Content |location=Madison |publisher=University of Wisconsin-Madison: The Writing Center |work=Writer's Handbook |accessdate=2008-03-02 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080304040827/http://www.wisc.edu/writing/Handbook/AnnBib_content.html| archivedate= 4 March 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Informative annotations provide a straight summary of the source material.
They summarise all relevant information about the author and the main points of the work.
To write an informative annotation, begin by writing the thesis; then develop it with the argument or hypothesis, list the proofs, and state the conclusion
'''Indicative annotated bibliographies'''
Indicative annotations do not provide actual information from the source.
They provide overall information about what kinds of questions or issues are addressed by the work, for example, through chapter titles.
In the indicative entry, there is no attempt to give actual data such as hypotheses, proofs, etc.
===Evaluative annotations=== This type of annotation assesses the source's strengths and weaknesses, in terms of usefulness and quality.<ref name=annbib />
Evaluative annotated bibliographies do more than just summarising, they provide critical appraisals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://help.library.ubc.ca/planning-your-research/how-to-write-an-annotated-bibliography/|title=How to Write an Annotated Bibliography|last=The University of British Columbia|first=|date=August 10, 2016|website=Planning Your Research|publisher=The University of British Columbia|access-date=August 10, 2016}}</ref>
They evaluate the source or author critically to find any biases, lack of evidence, objectives, etc.
They show how the work may or may not be useful for a particular field of study or audience.
They explain how researching this material assisted your own project.
===Combination annotations=== Most annotated bibliographies contain combination annotations. This type of annotation will summarize or describe the topic, and then evaluate the source's usefulness and a summary. Usually also includes a detailed analysis on the reason the article was written.<ref name=annbib />
== Formats of writing annotated bibliographies == Annotated bibliographies contain two main sections; the bibliographic information section and the annotations section.
Since the formats may slightly vary from one institution to another and amongst scholars and researchers depending on the regulations, courses and materials being annotated, it is imperative to ask for specific guidelines.
'''The bibliographic information'''
There are also bibliography annotations that combine all three types (MLA, APA and Chicago style). When deciding on the style for your annotated bibliography, consider its purpose and the instructions given to you by your supervisor. Regardless of the formatting style required at your institution, all annotated bibliography pieces need to follow the same rule: the author’s last name should be the only part that is flush left, while the rest of the text requires to be indented.<ref>[https://domywriting.com/blog/annotated-bibliography-example/ ''Annotated Bibliography Example''] from the DoMyWriting's blog 2018. Retrieved August 07, 2018</ref>
The bibliographic information is written before the annotation using the suitable referencing style. The information is normally identified using a hanging indent.
Generally, though, the bibliographic information of the source (the title, author, publisher, date, etc.) is written in either MLA or APA format.
'''The annotations'''
The annotations for each source are written in paragraph form.
The lengths of the annotations can vary significantly from a couple of sentences to a couple of pages.
The length of the annotation should be between 100 to 200 words.
When writing summaries of sources, the annotations may not be very long.
However, when writing an extensive analysis of each source, more space may be needed.
A few sentences of general summary followed by several sentences of how you can fit the work into your larger paper or project can serve you well when you go to draft.
==Writing== Sample entry of an [[APA style]] annotated bibliography: {{quote box | border = 2px | align = left | bgcolor = Cornsilk | title = Murray, S. (2009). ''The library: An illustrated history'' (ALA ed.). Chicago, IL: Skyhorse Publishing. | halign = left | quote = <poem> Murray's book offers an in-depth look at the history of libraries since ancient times. He incorporates beautiful illustrations, quotations, and descriptions of numerous libraries worldwide. This book states the history of the evolution of the book from era to era. It also serves as a primary source of information for research in library history. This is a good book that should be of interest to book lovers and librarians. </poem> | salign = right | source = <ref>{{Cite web|url = https://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/614/03/|title = Purdue OWL|date = 2014|accessdate = 2014-10-24|website = OWL|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> }} {{clear}}
==References== {{reflist}}

{{unreferenced|date=January 2014}} The '''bookwriter''' is the member of a [[Musical theatre|musical]]'s writing team who creates the book—the musical's plot, character development, and dramatic structure. Essentially, the bookwriter is the playwright of the musical. He or she works very closely in collaboration with the [[lyricist]] and [[composer]] to create an integrated piece of drama.
There is a common misconception that the bookwriter merely writes the dialogue; though the book does include the musical's spoken text, it is much more than that, defining and organizing the dramatic action of the entire piece, including action that is musicalized by the songwriter(s). Even "sung-through," "operatic," or "through-composed" musicals, where there is little, if any, spoken text, require as much contribution from a bookwriter as do musicals with extensive dialogue scenes.
The bookwriter is often also the musical's lyricist, composer, or director.
[[Category:Occupations in music]]

{{italic title}} {{multiple issues | {{refimprove|date=April 2012}} {{overly detailed|date=June 2008}} {{review|date=April 2012}} }} '''Broadminded''' was a daily talk and entertainment show on [[SIRIUS XM Satelliete Radio]] Channel 107 – [[Sirius XM Stars]].
It was hosted by real-life friends, [[Christine Eads]] and [[Molly Dedham]]. The hosts refer to themselves as "''Broads''". They discussed a wide range of topics from sex, men, entertainment, and life in general. Christine and Molly met at George Mason University in the early 90's and have been best friends ever since. They often refer to living together in LA, doing random jobs together and even dating the same guy.
The show debuted on <ref>XM Radio</ref> XM Radio channel 105 <ref>Take 5</ref> TAKE 5 in October 2005. The show was originally heard from 8:00 – 10:00 PM evenings eastern time, but was quickly moved to the evening drive time slot, from 5:00 – 8:00 PM Eastern time, due to its popularity with listeners. In September 2007, their timeslot was again moved – this time to the 12:00 – 3:00 PM (EST) slot with encore re-broadcasts at 9:00 PM (EST).
The original Broadminded show consisted of three '''"Broads",''' which included '''Molly, Christine''' and '''[[Shari Elliker]]. Shari's''' last show was on December 21, 2007. '''Jason Moore''', of [[Panacea (group)]] fame, was the well-liked Board Operator (Board Op. for short) for the show and could be heard "chiming in" on the girls' rants from time to time.
After the merger between '''Sirius and XM satetellite radio companies''', '''Broadminded''' went on a hiatus for six weeks in the beginning of 2009, and when they returned on March 17, 2009, to '''Sirius 102 and XM 155 The Stars Channels''' their time was changed to 12:00 – 2:00 PM (EST), with replays 8:00 – 10:00 PM (EST) Monday – Friday.
On November 3, 2009, '''Broadminded''' aired live from 2:00 – 4:00 PM (EST), with replays 10:00 PM – 12:00 AM (EST) Monday – Friday.
As of January 3, 2011, '''Broadminded''' is now live on the morning drive time slot, 8:00 – 10:00 AM (EST).
As of March 2013, the show was cancelled.
== Specialities ==
'''Christine''' is a fan of entertainment and gossip and leads the other broads daily during Broadbuzz. Christine also seems to be the driving force during Ask The Broads/As Tried on Broadminded and The Unbelivable Broads. Her passion for her charity The Duffy House is now a part of a monthly segment Christine does the second Tuesday of each month to raise awareness about Domestic and Sexual abuse and Violence.
'''Molly''' is a fan of music and movies, and you will hear a Molly's Music segment every Thursday ranging from singing to the songs of the 80s onto a Tribute to Marvin Gaye. Molly also will give you all the scoop on movies before they hit the theaters and tell you what is worth watching and what to skip at the theaters. Molly will get the 'behind the scenes' interviews with Directors and Actors for your favorite movies.
The opening sequence to their show has recently been changed to reflect these interests.
'''The Broads''' Love American Idol, Bachelor, Bachelorette, Batchelor Pad, True Blood, Dancing With The Stars, Two and a Half Men, Game of Thrones, and you can hear their recaps weekly.
'''The Broads''' also host the Telluride film festival for '''Starz Entertainment TV Channel'''.
== Popular Segments and Guests == #'''PSYCHIC: Reverend Sherry Sherry''': [[<ref>Sherry Sherry</ref> Sherry Sherry]] Internationally known '''<ref>Psychic Sherry Sherry</ref> Psychic Sherry Sherry''' is with the '''Broads''' EVERY MONDAY. She does a call in show for listeners to get psychic insights & guidance, have their personal questions answered, and to help them connect with loved ones in spirit. She also gives readings to the Broads on their love lives, and makes (very accurate) celebrity predictions. Her accurate predictions on Broadminded have been quoted in: ''<ref>USA Today</ref> USA Today,'' <ref>USA Today Sports Weekly</ref> USA ''Today Sports Weekly,'' ''<ref>Washington Post</ref> The Washington Post'', and ''<ref>The National Journal</ref> The National Journal'' (Capital Hill Magazine: Accurate Election Predictions). The call in number is 1-866-267-0447. #'''Broad Buzz''': This is an entertainment/gossip feature, with pithy comments and observations by the Broads. #'''Unbelievable Broad''': This is usually a profile on a woman who is making a difference in the world. #'''Connie – "The Sports Broad"''': A regular guest in which the Broads discuss topics in the Sports World. #'''Bill Glasser from <ref>'''Americas Most Wanted'''</ref> America's Most Wanted''': He covers the important stories that will be featured on the show, which airs Saturdays 9 p.m. ET/PT, 8 p.m. CT on <ref>FOX Television</ref>'''Fox'''. Help the Broads and AMW catch these creeps!!! #'''Damian Holbrook''' from <ref>'''TV Guide'''</ref>'''TV Guide Magazine''' and tvguidemagazine.com is a huge part of the show, joining the broads every Thursday.
== References == <references />

[[Category:American talk radio programs]] [[Category:Women's media]]

{{More footnotes|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Bruno Zevi | image = Bruno Zevi.png | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = {{birth date|1918|1|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = Rome, Italy | death_date = {{death date and age|2000|1|9|1918|1|22|df=yes}} | death_place = Rome, Italy | education = | occupation = Architecture critic, architect, historian, author | alma_mater = [[University of Rome La Sapienza|University of Rome]], [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]] | title = | family = | spouse = Tullia Zevi (m. 1940) | nationality = Italian | children = | credits = | URL = }}
'''Bruno Zevi''' (22 January 1918 – 9 January 2000) was an Italian architect, historian, professor, curator, author, and editor. Zevi was a vocal critic of "classicizing" modern architecture and [[postmodernism]].
==Early life== Zevi was born and died in Rome. His family was [[Italian Jew]]ish.<ref>His kin never kept him from openly expressing his own ideas: Art Kutcher (''Politics could do more harm than the planners in Jerusalem'', [[The Times]] , Monday, Aug 25, 1975; pg. 6; Issue 59483) remembers a protest in 1970 against [[Teddy Kollek]], opposing the project of building an underground parking near the [[Jaffa Gate]].</ref>
On finishing school in 1933, he enrolled at the Faculty of Architecture at the [[University of Rome La Sapienza|University of Rome]]. Due to the [[anti-Semitic]] laws, Zevi was forced in 1938 to abandon his studies, and so left for London, UK, before moving to the United States. Zevi graduated from the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]], then under the directorship of [[Walter Gropius]].
In 1940 he married Italian journalist and writer [[Tullia Zevi|Tullia Calabi]].<ref name="NY Times - 27Jan2011 - obits - Tullia Zevi">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/27/world/europe/27zevi.html|title=Tullia Zevi, 91; Led Italian Jewish Community|last=Donadio|first=Rachel|date=27 January 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|page=23|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> While in the US he discovered the work of [[Frank Lloyd Wright]], which became one of the bases for his championing of [[organic architecture]].<ref name="Zeier, 2014">{{cite book|last1=Pilat|first1=Stephanie Zeier|title=Reconstructing Italy: The Ina-Casa Neighborhoods of the Postwar Era|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781409465805|page=63|edition=US|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KPzsCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=Association+for+Organic+Architecture+(APAO)&source=bl&ots=LhYxDzni2S&sig=R1U7zR0ywjU3uX4_14SO3yof-XY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQ6KyNuYvUAhUD7iYKHd_bBQsQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=Association%20for%20Organic%20Architecture%20(APAO)&f=false|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref> Zevi returned to London in 1943, working as a translator in the war effort.
==Association for Organic Architecture== In 1944, he founded the influential Association for Organic Architecture (APAO).<ref name="Zeier, 2014" /> The following year the magazine ''Metron-architecture'' reviewed his book [https://www.amazon.com/Towards-Organic-Architecture-Bruno-Zevi/dp/B000WEKQ3A Towards an Organic Architecture] (published in English by [[Faber and Faber|Faber]] in 1950), which brought him international acclaim.
[[Image:IMG 0387 - scalea Bruno Zevi.jpg|thumb|300px|A stairway in Rome named in his honor]]
==University professor== In 1945, Zevi became Professor of Architectural History at the [[University of Venice]]. Later, he was a Professor at the [[University of Rome La Sapienza|University of Rome]], and a member of the [[International Academy of Architecture]] (IAA) in Sofia, Bulgaria.
==Editor, writer and politician== From 1955 onwards, he wrote a column for the weekly ''[[L'Espresso]]'' magazine. He was an active member of the Italian Jewish community, and took part in anti-fascist activities within the [[Giustizia e Libertà]] movement. He was active in the [[Action Party (Italy)|Action Party]] and later in [[Popular Unity (Italy)|Popular Unity]] and in the [[Radical Party (Italy)|Radical Party]], which he represented in the [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] from 1987 to 1992. From 1954 until his death in 2000 he was editor of his own magazine ''[[L'architettura. Cronache e storia]]''.
''The Modern Language of Architecture'' is one of Zevi’s most significant publications. In this book Zevi sets forth seven principles or “antirules” to codify the language of architecture created by [[Le Corbusier]], [[Walter Gropius|Gropius]], [[Mies van der Rohe]], and [[Frank Lloyd Wright|Wright]]. In place of the classical language of the Beaux Art school, with its focus on abstract principles of order, proportion, and symmetry, he presents an alternative system of communication characterized by a free interpretation of contents and function, an emphasis on difference and dissonance, a dynamic of multidimensional vision, and independent interplay of elements, an organic marriage of engineering and design, a concept of living spaces that are designed for use, and an integration of buildings into their surroundings. Anticipating the innovations of postmodern architecture, Zevi argues forcefully for complexity and against unity, for decomposition dialogue between architecture and historiography, finding elements of the modern language of architecture throughout history, and discussing the process of architectural innovation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zevi|first1=Bruno|title=The modern language of architecture|date=1978|publisher=University of Washington Press|location=Seattle|isbn=9780295955681|url=https://www.abebooks.com/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=13470360009&searchurl=isbn%3D9780295955681%26sortby%3D17|accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref>
==Architecture as space== Zevi argued in ''Saper Vedere L'Architettura'' (1948, translated as ''Architecture as Space. How to Look at Architecture'') that space is essential for both the definition and appreciation of architecture.<ref>Andrea Sauchelli, [http://philpapers.org/rec/SAUOAA 'On Architecture as a Spatial Art'], ''[http://nsae.au.dk/the-journal Nordic Journal of Aesthetics]'', 43 (2012)</ref>
==Modern architecture movement== Zevi participated in the influential International Architecture Symposium "Mensch und Raum" (Man and Space) at the [[Vienna University of Technology]] (Technische Universität Wien) in 1984, also attended by [[Justus Dahinden]], Ernst Gisel, [[Jorge Glusberg]], Otto Kapfinger, [[Frei Otto]], [[Ionel Schein]], [[Dennis Sharp]], [[Paolo Soleri]], and [[Pierre Vago]].
Such was Zevi's uncompromising critique of any tendency in modern architecture towards classicism that he even would criticize those architects he otherwise admired: "When [[Walter Gropius|Gropius]], [[Ludwig Mies van der Rohe|Mies]] and [[Alvar Aalto|Aalto]] produced [symmetrical buildings] it was an act of surrender. Lacking a modern code, they weakened and regressed to the familiar womb of classicism." (Zevi, ''The Modern Language of Architecture'').
== Quotes == "In 1973, Zevi set out (his) ideas as a set of invariants - a sort of anti-classical codebook that attempted to define modernity as a language of asymmetry and dissonance, which he propagated via his magazine L'architettura, cronache e storia. This exciting theory of architecture as rupture and fragmentation marks him out as the seminal theoretician for all currents of modernism interested in iconoclasm and deconstruction, from [[Alvar Aalto]] in the 1930s to [[Daniel Libeskind]] in the 1990s." (Thomas Muirhead, March 1, 2000; ''The Guardian'', Obituary, 2000)<ref>Thomas Muirhead, [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2000/mar/01/guardianobituaries1 'Bruno Zevi, Architectural philosopher who railed against the evils of classicism'], ''[[The Guardian]]'', Wednesday 1 March 2000</ref>
== Select publications== * Bruno Zevi, ''Verso un’architettura organica'', Giulio Einaudi editore, Torino 1945 (English translation, ''Towards an Organic Architecture'', Faber & Faber, London 1950) * Bruno Zevi, ''Saper vedere l’architettura'', Giulio Einaudi editore, Torino 1948 (English translation, ''Architecture as Space. How to look at Architecture'', Horizon Press, New York 1957; Da Capo Press, New York 1993) * Bruno Zevi, ''Storia dell’architettura moderna'', Giulio Einaudi editore, Torino 1950 e 1975 * Bruno Zevi, ''Architecture as Space: How to Look at Architecture'', Horizon Press, New York 1957 * Bruno Zevi, ''Spazi dell’architettura moderna'', Giulio Einaudi editore, Torino 1973 * Bruno Zevi, ''Cronache di architettura <sub>(volumi I-XXIV, saggi 1-1276)</sub>'', Editori Laterza, Roma - Bari, seconda edizione 1978 * Bruno Zevi, ''Editoriali di architettura <sub>(Architetti e linguggio, Crtici e liguistica, Paesaggi e citta, Avanguardia e restaurazione, Design come ragione civile, Not quite architecture)</sub>'', Giulio Einaudi editore, Torino 1979 * Bruno Zevi, ''Michelangiolo architetto'', edited with [[Paolo Portoghesi|P. Portoghesi]], Giulio Einaudi editore, Torino 1964 * Bruno Zevi, ''Erich Mendelsohn Opera Completa'', Etas Kompass, Milano 1970; Testo & Immagine, Torino 1997 (English translation, ''Erich Mendelsohn - The Complete Works'', Birkhäuser Verlag, Berlin, 1999)
==References== {{reflist}}
* {{cite book|author=Roberto Dulio|year=2008|title=[http://www.laterza.it/index.php?option=com_laterza&Itemid=99&task=schedalibro&isbn=9788842087168 ''Introduzione a Bruno Zevi'']| publisher= Editori Laterza, Roma-Bari 2008|isbn=9788842087168}}. * Andrea Sauchelli, [http://ojs.statsbiblioteket.dk/index.php/nja/article/view/7497/6345 'On Architecture as a Spatial Art'], ''[http://nsae.au.dk/the-journal Nordic Journal of Aesthetics]'', 43 (2012) * [[Ruggero Lenci]] Encyclopedia Italiana Treccani, V appendix |url = http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/bruno-zevi_(Enciclopedia-Italiana)/ |
== External links == * {{archINFORM|arch|3885}} * [http://www.fondazionebrunozevi.it Foundation Bruno Zevi] * [https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,230995,00.html "Bruno Zevi" (The Guardian)] * [http://www.architetturaorganica.org ADAO - The International Web Portal of Organic Architecture]
{{Authority control}}

[[Image:Burghley_nef.jpg|thumb|The Burghley Nef, 1527-1528, France, V&A Museum no. M.60-1959]]
The '''Burghley Nef''' is a [[silver-gilt]] [[salt cellar]] made in Paris in 1527–28 (or possibly earlier). In medieval France the word [[Nef (metalwork)|nef]] was applied to various types of boat-shaped containers, including the most magnificent objects intended for the dining tables and buffets of the rich. Apart from having an obvious ornamental quality, their function was to hold personal pieces of cutlery or, as in this case, [[salt]] or [[spice]]s—there is a detachable compartment on the rear deck, which was presumably passed around the table. This [[nautilus shell]], mounted in silver, was a rare natural curiosity.
The Burghley Nef would have been placed in front of the most important person at table as a mark of their status. At the foot of the mast, engaged in a game of chess, are the tiny figures of the lovers [[Tristan and Iseult]] who, according to the legend, mistakenly drank a love potion and suffered tragic consequences. The Burghley Nef is currently in the collection of the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in [[London]]. It was discovered at [[Burghley House]] in 1956 and sold on 17 July 1959 when the [[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter|6th Marquess of Exeter]] auctioned part of his silver collection.
==Bibliography== *{{cite book|title=V&A: A Hundred Highlights|year=2001|publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum|isbn=9781851773657|editor-first=Anna |editor-last=Jackson}}
== External links == {{Commonscat-inline}} *[http://www.artfund.org/artwork/3484/the-burghley-nef Art Fund] *[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O73113/salt-cellar-the-burghley-nef/ The Burghley Nef at the Victoria and Albert Museum]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=July 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = town | name = Byron Bay | state = nsw | image = Bryon Bay NSW.jpg | caption = Byron Bay from Cape Byron State Conservation Area | coordinates = {{coord|28|38|35|S|153|36|54|E|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_label_position = left | pop = 9246 | pop_year = [[2016 Australian census|2016 census]] | pop_footnotes={{Census 2016 AUS|id=UCL114003|name=Byron Bay (Urban Centre/Locality)|accessdate=1 October 2018|quick=on}}[[File:CC-BY icon.svg|50px]] Material was copied from this source, which is available under a [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016050101/https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/# |date=16 October 2017 }}. | postcode = 2481 | elevation= 3 | location1= [[Sydney]] | dist2 = 165 | location2= [[Brisbane]] | lga = Byron Shire | county = [[Rous County|Rous]] | stategov = [[Electoral district of Ballina|Ballina]] | fedgov = [[Division of Richmond|Richmond]] | maxtemp = 23.5 | mintemp = 16.9 | rainfall = 1509.2 }} [[File:Byron lighthouse.jpg|thumb|Byron Bay Lighthouse]] [[File:Byron Lighthouse looking south 2004-28-12.JPG|thumb|Tallow Beach looking south from the lighthouse]] [[File:Wategos.JPG|thumb|Overlooking Wategos with Julian Rocks in the background]] [[File:Byron Bay New South Wales.jpg|thumb|Byron Bay with sugar cane burning in the distance]] '''Byron Bay''' is a beachside town located in the [[Northern Rivers|far-northeastern corner]] of the state of [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]]. It is located {{convert|772|km|mi|0}} north of [[Sydney]] and {{convert|165|km|mi|0}} south of [[Brisbane]]. [[Cape Byron]], a headland adjacent to the town, is the easternmost point of mainland Australia. At the [[2016 Australian census|2016 census]], the town had a permanent population of 9,246. The town is in turn the nucleus of [[Byron Shire]], which had 31,556 residents.{{Census 2016 AUS|id=LGA11350|name=Byron Shire |accessdate=1 October 2018|quick=on}}[[File:CC-BY icon.svg|50px]] Material was copied from this source, which is available under a [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171016050101/https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/# |date=16 October 2017 }}. The local [[Bundjalung people|Arakwal]] Aboriginal people's name for the area is ''Cavvanbah'', meaning "meeting place".{{cite web|url=http://www.theherald.com.au/story/1503982/buck-passing-threatens-aboriginal-lifeline/|title=Aboriginal elders gather at historic meeting place|work=[[The Newcastle Herald]]|accessdate=16 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324075539/http://www.theherald.com.au/story/1503982/buck-passing-threatens-aboriginal-lifeline/#|archive-date=24 March 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Lieutenant [[James Cook]] named Cape Byron after Naval officer [[John Byron]], circumnavigator of the world and grandfather of the poet [[Lord Byron]].{{NSW GNR|id=KWjLjzUlJP|title=Byron Bay|accessdate=28 June 2009}} == History == The history of Europeans in Byron Bay began in 1770, when Lieutenant [[James Cook]] found a safe anchorage and named [[Cape Byron]] after a fellow sailor [[John Byron]].{{cite book |last1=Watson |first1=Penny |editor1-first=Justine |editor1-last=Vaisutis |title=Lonely Planet: Australia |edition= 15|date=November 2009 |publisher=Lonely Planet Publications |isbn= |page= 195 |chapter= New South Wales |quote= The Grandfather of the [...] poet Lord Byron was a renowned navigator in the 1760s, and Captain Cook named this spot after [...] him. (In the 1880s, when Europeans settled more permanently, streets were named for other English writers and philosophers. A star-struck clerk in Sydney thought the grandson was the one being honoured, and named the streets – and the town – after poets: [[John Keats|Keats]], [[Ben Jonson|Jonson]], [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]].)}} The first industry in Byron was cedar logging from the Australian red cedar (''[[Toona ciliata]]''). The timber industry is the origin of the word "shoot" in many local names – Possum Shoot, Coopers Shoot and Skinners Shoot – where the timber-cutters would "shoot" the logs down the hills to be dragged to waiting ships.{{Cite web |url=http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/early-settlement/# |title=Byron Bay Historical Society: Early Settlement |access-date=27 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180815012228/http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/early-settlement/# |archive-date=15 August 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Timber getting became insignificant after [[World War I]] and many former timber workers became farmers. Gold mining of the beaches was the next industry to occur. Up to 20 mining leases set up on Tallow Beach to extract gold from the black sands around the 1870s. Byron Bay has a history of primary industrial production ([[dairy]] factory,''Creamery Tramway at Byron Bay'' Longworth, Jim [[Australian Railway History|Australian Railway Historical Society Bulletin]], October 1996, pp. 295–298. [[abattoirs]], fishing, and [[whaling]] until 1963) and was a significant, but hazardous, sea port. The poet Brunton Stephens spoke of cattle grazing on the "mossy plains" of Cape Byron in a poem he penned in 1876. The first [[jetty]] was built in 1886, and the railway was connected in 1894, and Cavvanbah became Byron Bay in 1894. Dairy farmers cleared more land and settled the area. In 1895, the [[Norco Co-operative]] was formed to provide cold storage and manage the dairy industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.norco.com.au/publish/history/index.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=7 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012104655/http://www.norco.com.au/publish/history/index.php |archivedate=12 October 2008 }} The introduction of [[paspalum]] improved production, and Byron Bay exported butter to the world. The Norco factory was the biggest in the southern hemisphere,{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} expanding from dairy to [[bacon]] and other processed meat. The [[lighthouse]] was built in 1901 at the most easterly point on the Australian mainland. In 1930, the first meatworks opened.{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Beauty-and-the-beast/2005/03/20/1111253864398.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Beauty and the beast | date=20 March 2005 | access-date=7 October 2008 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410102812/http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Beauty-and-the-beast/2005/03/20/1111253864398.html# | archive-date=10 April 2008 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} The smell from the meat and dairy works was, by all accounts, appalling,{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} and the annual slaughter of migrating whales in the 1950s and 1960s made matters worse. [[Sand mining]] for [[monazite]] ([[zircon]], [[uranium]] and [[thorium]]) between the World Wars damaged the environment further,[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/planmanagement/final/20120399CumbebinSwampNRFinal.pdf Cumbebin swamp nature reserve] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625123057/http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/planmanagement/final/20120399CumbebinSwampNRFinal.pdf# |date=25 June 2014 }} ''[[National Parks and Wildlife Service (New South Wales)]]'' page 20{{cite web|url= http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/population/ |title=Industry|date=19 June 2014|publisher= |accessdate=28 September 2017 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170310191149/http://byronbayhistoricalsociety.org.au/development-of-byron-bay/population/ |archive-date=2017-03-10 |dead-url= no }}{{cite web|url=https://mrdata.usgs.gov/ree/show-ree.php?rec_id=514|title=Newrybar (Record #514 rare-earth element deposit in New South Wales, Australia|work=mrdata.usgs.gov|accessdate=28 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929000925/https://mrdata.usgs.gov/ree/show-ree.php?rec_id=514#|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and one by one, all these industries declined.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} [[Longboard (surfing)|Longboard]] [[Surfing|surfers]] arrived in the 1960s and used natural breaks at The Pass, Watego's, and Cosy Corner. This was the beginning of Byron Bay as a travellers' destination, and by 1973, when the [[Aquarius Festival]] was held in nearby [[Nimbin, New South Wales|Nimbin]], its reputation as a [[hippie|hippy]], happy, [[alternative lifestyle|alternative]] town was established, although tourism facilities remained minimal.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=YwkuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61&lpg=PA55|pp=55-63|title=New Voices, New Visions: Challenging Australian Identities and Legacies|editor1=Catriona Elder|editor2=Keith Moore|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|year=2012|ISBN=1-4438-3756-3|access-date=28 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929001056/https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=YwkuBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61&lpg=PA55#|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} From the 1980s, tourism began to develop in earnest, with the cash-poor surfers and hippies supplemented, and to a degree supplanted, by cashed-up conspicuous consumers who in turn stimulated the development of retail precincts and accommodation more tuned to their needs. Today, Byron Bay is one of the most up-market residential areas on the Australian east coast with the growth in multi-million dollar mansions now pushing the median value of house sales up beyond AU$1.5 million in 2017, over a 100% increase since 2013, based on 2018 data from realestate.com.au.[https://www.realestate.com.au/invest/house-in-byron+bay,+nsw+2481 realestate.com.au data for Byron Bay, NSW] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180827142504/https://www.realestate.com.au/invest/house-in-byron+bay,+nsw+2481# |date=27 August 2018 }} (retrieved 27 August 2018) At the same time, the town has not lost its attraction to a diverse range of visitors including surfers, backpackers and general tourists interested in the natural attractions of the area, and also supports a healthy cross section of creative persons including artists, craftspersons and musicians, while its more recent hippy/new age past is reflected to a degree in a prevalence of alternative "new-age" shops, "spiritual" services such as meditation and yoga classes, and holistic healing/"wellness" retreats.Wray, Meredith, Laing, Jennifer and Voigt, Cornelia. 2010. "Byron Bay: an alternate health and wellness destination." ''Journal of Hospitality and Tourism Management'' Volume 17, Issue 1, Pages 158-166. DOI:10.1375/jhtm.17.1.158 As at 2018, the town is cited as having around 5,000 permanent residents, while being visited by over 1.5 million tourists each year.[http://www.destinationbyron.com.au/our-shire/ Destination Byron: Our Shire] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828072605/http://www.destinationbyron.com.au/our-shire/# |date=28 August 2018 }} (entry for Byron Bay) A number of shipwrecks litter the bay and surrounding areas.NSW Heritage office: "Shipwrecks - Byron Bay." Available online at https://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/heritagebranch/maritime/shipwrecksbyron.pdf == Population == According to the [[Census in Australia#2016|2016 census]] of Population, there were 9,246 people in Byron Bay. * Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 1.6% of the population. * 64.0% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 4.9% and New Zealand 2.5%. * 76.3% of people spoke only English at home. * The most common response for religion was No Religion at 44.6%. == Geography == Byron Bay is part of the erosion [[caldera]] of an ancient [[shield volcano]], the [[Tweed Volcano]], which had erupted 23 million years ago. The volcano formed as a result of the [[Indo-Australian Plate]] moving over the [[East Australia hotspot]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bigvolcano.com.au/natural/lostwrld.htm|title=The Lost World|publisher=Big Volcano Visitor Guide|accessdate=19 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130314025525/http://www.bigvolcano.com.au/natural/lostwrld.htm#|archive-date=14 March 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} == Climate == Byron Bay has a [[humid subtropical climate]] (''Cfa'' in the [[Köppen climate classification]]) with warm summers and mild winters. Winters have daily maximums usually reaching 19.4 °C and a minimum of 12 °C. Summer can be hot, with a daily average of 27 °C. Summer evenings can be wet, cooling the day down.

== Tourism == [[File:Byron Bay (Australia) main Beach from town.JPG|thumb|The main beach in 2006]] [[File:Byron Bay Lighthouse.JPG|thumb|[[Cape Byron Light|Byron Bay Lighthouse]]]] The town has several beaches which are popular for [[surfing]]. It is a resort popular with both domestic and international tourists, including [[backpacking (urban)|backpackers]], who travel along the Australian coast; the scenery also attracts skydivers. The area is also noted for its wildlife, with the [[whale watching]] industry a significant contributor to the local economy.{{cite web|url=http://www.visitnsw.com/destinations/north-coast/byron-bay-area/byron-bay|title=Byron Bay|publisher=Visit NSW|accessdate=19 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121208035053/http://www.visitnsw.com/destinations/north-coast/byron-bay-area/byron-bay#|archive-date=8 December 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} An [[oceanway]] runs from the centre of town to the Cape Byron lighthouse. This allows visitors to walk and cycle to the lighthouse. Temperate and tropical waters merge at Byron Bay, making it a popular area for [[scuba diving]] and [[snorkelling]]. Most diving is done at [[Julian Rocks]] which is part of the recently established [[Cape Byron Marine Park]] and only a few minutes boat ride from Main Beach.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} Byron Bay also lies close to subtropical rainforests, and areas such as the [[Nightcap National Park]] with the [[Minyon Falls]] are all within easy reach of the town. Byron Bay is now also a popular destination for [[Schoolies week]] during late November and early December.{{cite news|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/byron-bay-schoolies-put-gold-coast-to-shame-20091130-jzb8.html|title=Byron Bay Schoolies 'put Gold Coast to shame'|date=30 November 2009|publisher=[[Brisbane Times]]|access-date=29 July 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091203103359/http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/byron-bay-schoolies-put-gold-coast-to-shame-20091130-jzb8.html#|archive-date=3 December 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Heritage listings== Byron Bay has a number of heritage-listed sites, including: * Casino-Murwillumbah railway: [[Byron Bay railway station]]{{cite NSW SHR|5011962|Byron Bay Railway Station and yard group|hr=01107|accessdate=18 May 2018}} * 61 Jonson Street: [[Byron Bay Post Office]]{{cite AHD|106175|Byron Bay Post Office|fn=1/01/111/0023|accessdate=15 September 2018}} ==Events== Festivals held in Byron Bay include the [[East Coast Blues & Roots Music Festival]] at Easter, [[Falls Festival]] NYE and [[Splendour in the Grass]], the Byron Bay International Fashion Festival{{Cite web |url=http://bbiff.com.au/# |title=Byron Bay International Fashion Festival |access-date=22 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913174625/http://bbiff.com.au/# |archive-date=13 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} on 29 April each year, the [[Byron Bay Writers Festival]],{{cite web |url= http://www.byronbaywritersfestival.com.au/v2/index.php |title=Byron Bay Writers' Festival |publisher=Northern Rivers Writers' Centre |accessdate=19 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114034044/http://www.byronbaywritersfestival.com.au/v2/index.php |archivedate=14 January 2013 }} the [[Byron Bay Film Festival]], Byron Bay Surf Festival, Byron Spirit Festival and the Byron Underwater Festival.{{cite web|url=http://festival.underwater.com.au/ |title=Welcome to the Underwater Festival 2012 |publisher=Underwater Australasia |accessdate=19 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302225152/http://festival.underwater.com.au/ |archivedate=2 March 2013 |df=dmy }} The Byron Bay [[Triathlon]] is held on the second Saturday in May every year. 1,300 competitors from many different countries enter this Olympic Distance event. The vibrant musical community has produced internationally renowned bands such as [[Blue King Brown]], [[Parkway Drive (band)|Parkway Drive]] and [[50 Lions]]. ==Markets== Byron Bay has a number of regular markets including a weekly [[farmers' market]]{{cite web|url=http://byronfarmersmarket.com.au/|title=Byron Farmers' Market|accessdate=19 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813000706/http://byronfarmersmarket.com.au/#|archive-date=13 August 2011|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} at the Butler Street Reserve every Thursday with over 70 local farmers selling fresh produce. There is also a Byron Community Market held on the same site on the first Sunday of each month and the Artisan Market held on Saturday evenings at Railway Park from October to Easter. There are three annual specialist Beachside Markets held in January, Easter and September.{{cite web|url=http://www.byroncentre.com.au/|title=Byron Markets|publisher=Byron Community Centre|accessdate=15 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141215054341/http://www.byroncentre.com.au/#|archive-date=15 December 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Transport== A bus station in Jonson Street is serviced by [[Greyhound Australia]], [[NSW TrainLink]] and [[Premier Transport Group|Premier Motor Services]] coach services from [[Sydney]] and [[Brisbane]]. The [[Byron Bay Railroad Company|Byron Bay Train]] service will operate as a shuttle between Byron Bay station in the Byron township and North Beach station. The privately run service operates on a 3 km section of the disused [[Murwillumbah railway line|Murwillimbah line]]. It is expected to open by Christmas 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.broadsheet.com.au/national/city-file/article/worlds-first-solar-powered-train-heads-byron-bay|title=The World’s First Solar-Powered Train Heads to Byron Bay|work=Broadsheet|access-date=2017-10-29|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029121255/https://www.broadsheet.com.au/national/city-file/article/worlds-first-solar-powered-train-heads-byron-bay#|archive-date=29 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} [[Byron Bay railway station]] was a stop on the [[Murwillumbah railway line|Casino to Murwillumbah railway line]] until 2004. It was served by trains from Sydney and for various periods also by services originating at Casino that connected with expresses running between Sydney and South Brisbane. A 3.4 km section of the Murwillumbah railway line is to be rehabilitated in 2016 for a two car self-propelled diesel train planned to run from the town centre to the Elements of Byron resort and nearby attractions. An earlier local train service, known as the Byron Bay Tram conveyed passengers from about 1928 until about 1954 between the railway station and the "new jetty" where connections were made with passenger carrying ships of the North Coast Steam Navigation Company. Motive power was a Simplex petrol locomotive, locally known as the "Green Frog", and the passenger vehicles comprised former Newcastle B2 class steam tram trailer 74B and former Sydney C class electric tram C37. After the trams stopped running both the cars went to a heritage tramway in Parramatta Park where 74B was destroyed by fire. The Simplex was built in Bedford England and went into service in 1923 shunting freight to and from the "old" jetty adjacent to the township and then to "new" jetty to the north when it was completed in 1928. Later it hauled whales from the jetty to the rendering down works, livestock to the meat works, mineral sands and meat wagons to the station for onward movement and regularly shunted Norco and other railway sidings and between these duties ran the passenger tramway until the coastal passenger shipping service stopped. The Simplex locomotive was retired in 1984 when the meat works closed and is now stored in a shed near the Kendall Street level crossing under the care of volunteers and the Byron Bay Council. == Education == Byron Bay schools include Byron Bay Public School, [[Byron Bay High School]], St Finbarr's Primary School, Byron Bay Community School, and [[Cape Byron Rudolf Steiner School]]. Among these are a number of early childhood facilities including Byron Bay Preschool and Periwinkle Preschool. In the fields of adult education there are Lexis English Centres (previously Global Village English Centres) and Byron Bay English Language School (BBELS) (both organisations providing English language tuition to international students), the Byron Region Community College, which is a registered training organisation and the SAE Institute Byron Bay which is a government-accredited, degree granting institution in the fields of audio engineering, digital film making, multimedia and animation. == Sport and recreation == The Byron Bay Surf Club is the longest-standing current sports club; it has been one of Australia's leading surf clubs and has been in continuous operation for more than 105 years. The [[rugby league]] club the [[Byron Bay Red Devils]] and the [[Australian rules football]] team [[Byron Football Club|Byron Magpies]] are well known. Byron Bay FC has won the Football Far North Coast Premier league three times, most recently in 2013. Other clubs include Byron Bay Golf Club, Byron Bay Cricket Club, Byron Bay Rugby Union Club, Byron Bay Gliding Club, Byron Bay Hang Gliding / Paragliding Club and the Byron Bay Bowling Club. The Byron Bay Ocean Swim Classic is held every year. == Media == The Byron Bay area has a number of newspapers: * ''The [[Byron Shire Echo]]'' (Independent weekly A3) * ''The Byron Shire News'' (APN weekly A3) * ''The Saturday Star'' (Independent A5 monthly) * ''The Bagg'' (Independent weekly A3 gig guide) * ''[[The Northern Star]]'' (APN daily, produced in nearby [[Lismore, New South Wales|Lismore]]) The community radio station [[Bay FM (Byron Bay)|Bay FM]] broadcasts on 99.9 FM from within Byron Bay itself. Other local stations in the Byron area are: * 2LM 900 AM (commercial) * [[100.9 ZZZ FM]] (commercial) * [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] Northern Rivers 94.5 FM * [[2NCR|River-FM]] 92.9 FM (community) All major television channels are available in Byron Bay and the wider Northern Rivers region: * [[Prime7]], [[Prime7HD]] [[7Two]], [[7mate]], [[7flix]], [[ishoptv]] ([[Seven Network]]/[[Prime Television]] affiliated channels, major-commercial) * [[9NBN]], [[9HD]] [[9Go!]], [[9Gem]], [[9Life]], [[Aspire TV]] ([[Nine Network]]/[[Southern Cross Austereo]], major-commercial) * [[WIN Television]], [[WIN HD]], [[WIN One]], [[WIN Eleven]], [[WIN Gold]] ([[Network Ten]]/[[WIN Corporation]], minor-commercial) * [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]], [[ABC HD (Australian TV channel)|ABC HD]], [[ABC Comedy]], [[ABC Kids (Australia)|ABC Kids]] and [[ABC ME]], [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] ([[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], semi-commercial) * [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]], [[SBS HD]], [[SBS Viceland]], [[SBS Viceland HD]] [[Food Network]], [[NITV]] ([[Special Broadcasting Service]], semi-commercial) ==Notable residents== * [[Daevid Allen]], musician * [[Renee Bargh]], TV presenter * [[John Butler (musician)|John Butler]], guitarist, founder of the [[John Butler Trio]] * [[Toni Childs]], musician * [[John Cornell]], businessman and [[Delvene Delaney]], actress and co-host of ''[[Sale of the Century (Australian game show)|Sale of the Century]]''[http://www.northernstar.com.au/news/cornell-delaney-sell-up-byron-properties/1655614/ Cornell. Delaney sell up Byron properties] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226000942/http://www.northernstar.com.au/news/cornell-delaney-sell-up-byron-properties/1655614/# |date=26 December 2014 }} ''[[The Northern Star]]'' 11 December 2012. * [[Eka Darville]], actor * [[Chris Hemsworth]], actor[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/chris-hemsworth-has-been-brutally-honest-about-hollywood-and-his-hatred-of-paparazzi-in-gq-interview/story-fni0cvc9-1227184955180]''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' 15 January 2015. * [[Elsa Pataky]], actress * [[In Hearts Wake]], metalcore band * [[The Jezabels]], lead singer Hayley Mary and keyboardist Heather Shannon * [[Kerry O'Brien (journalist)|Kerry O'Brien]], journalist[http://www.theweeklyreview.com.au/release/1822516-kerry-o-brien#.VJyI1jADUDk Kerry O'Brien] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225232604/http://www.theweeklyreview.com.au/release/1822516-kerry-o-brien#.VJyI1jADUDk |date=25 December 2014 }} ''The Weekly Review'' 11 August 2011. * [[Parkway Drive]], a metalcore band formed in 2002 that have toured around the world several times * [[Ric Richardson]], inventor[http://m.smh.com.au/it-pro/security-it/microsoft-patent-victor-ric-richardson-working-on-nopassword-security-breakthrough-20140422-zqvwk.html Ric Richardson] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712162541/http://m.smh.com.au/it-pro/security-it/microsoft-patent-victor-ric-richardson-working-on-nopassword-security-breakthrough-20140422-zqvwk.html# |date=12 July 2015 }} ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 22 April 2014. * [[Scott Owen]], bassist for [[The Living End]] * [[Space Cowboy (performer)|The Space Cowboy]], a record-breaking "sword swallower" and street performer who hails from Byron Bay * [[Peter Gifford]], bassist for [[Midnight Oil]] * [[Mouche Phillips]], actress * [[Simon Baker]], actor * [[Olivia Newton-John]], singer, songwriter, actress, novelist * [[Elle Macpherson]], model, entrepreneur * [[Jack Johnson (musician)|Jack Johnson]], musician * [[Naomi Watts]], actress * [[Jordan Barrett]], fashion model ===Former notable residents=== * [[Paul Hogan]], actor, and [[Linda Kozlowski]], actress[http://www.northernstar.com.au/news/who-owns-hoges-house-now/1565819/ Who owns Hoges' house now?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226000933/http://www.northernstar.com.au/news/who-owns-hoges-house-now/1565819/# |date=26 December 2014 }} ''The Northern Star'' 2 October 2012. * William (Bill) Clifford, General Manager of NORCO in the 1920s, described as founder of the dairy industry, lived in Byron Bay from the late nineteenth century until the 1920s.Plaque on a memorial to Bill Clifford in front of Byron Bay railway station; A Few Geraniums, the story of Elizabeth Smith Beryl Moore 2009 * [[Parcels (band)|Parcels]], band, formed at [[Byron Bay High School]], now based in Berlin{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/parcels-interview|title=Boyeurism: Parcels|last=Pentelow|first=Orla|work=Vogue|date=9 May 2017|access-date=12 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201035401/http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/parcels-interview#|archive-date=1 December 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} == In fiction == John Macgregor's 1986 novel ''[[Propinquity (novel)|Propinquity]]'' is partly set in Byron Bay and nearby [[Mullumbimby]]. The 2008/2009 [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] drama series ''[[East of Everything]]'', written by [[Deb Cox]] and Roger Monk, is set in the fictional town of Broken Bay which is based on a somewhat more run-down version of Byron Bay and its surrounds, with much of the filming taking place in and around Byron Bay including obviously recognisable landmarks such as the lighthouse and local beaches. The town also features in the 2016 [[open world]] racing video game, ''[[Forza Horizon 3]]''. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikivoyage|Byron Bay}} *{{Commons category inline|Byron Bay, New South Wales}} *{{cite web | publisher = [[Bureau of Meteorology]] | title=Byron Bay (Cape Byron Lighthouse) | work=Climate Averages for Australian Sites | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/averages/tables/cw_058009.shtml |accessdate = 2006-11-25}} * [http://nrgeology.blogspot.com.au/search/label/byron%20bay Northern Rivers Geology Blog – Byron Bay] *[http://www.visitnsw.com/destinations/north-coast/byron-bay-area/byron-bay/ visitnsw.com – Byron Bay] {{Northern Rivers region}} {{Australiansurf}} [[Category:Towns in New South Wales]] [[Category:Tweed Volcano]] [[Category:Bays of New South Wales]] [[Category:Northern Rivers]] [[Category:Entertainment districts in Australia]] [[Category:Surfing locations in New South Wales]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1770]] [[Category:Arts districts]] [[Category:Byron Bay, New South Wales| ]] [[Category:1770 establishments in the British Empire]] [[Category:Coastal towns in New South Wales]]
